description: A unique Buddhist temple built in 1049 by Emperor Ly Thai Tong, formally called Dien Huu Tu (Pagoda of Extended Blessings). The iconic structure sits on a single stone pillar rising from water, designed to resemble a lotus flower blooming from muddy waters. Regarded alongside the Huong Temple as one of Vietnam's two most iconic temples, it was rebuilt in 1955 after being destroyed in 1954.
highlights: Unique architecture - temple built on single 4-meter stone pillar
Pillar diameter: 1.2 meters representing lotus stem
Eight wooden beams forming eight flower petals
Red brick scale-tiled roof with four curved corners
Tam Quan Gate with carved Dien Huu Pagoda inscription
13 stairs representing fertility and prosperity wish
Bodhi tree gifted by Indian President Rajendra Prasad in 1958
Recognized by Asia Book of Records (2012) as unique pagoda in Asia
Located in Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum complex
tips: Located on Ong Ich Khiem Street, Doi Can Ward, Ba Dinh District
Best time to visit: August-November for lotus blossom season
Wear discreet, polite clothing - no shorts or skirts above knee
Walk softly and speak quietly inside
Pay attention to restricted area signs
Combine with visits to Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, Temple of Literature, Hoan Kiem Lake
vibe: Delicate yet enduring, the One Pillar Pagoda embodies the lotus flower rising pure from muddy waters - a Buddhist symbol of enlightenment. The ancient legend of Emperor Ly Thai Tong's dream adds mystical depth to this architectural wonder. Standing on its single pillar for nearly 1,000 years (with one rebuild), it represents both imperial devotion and engineering brilliance, offering visitors a moment of contemplation in one of Vietnam's most photographed and spiritually significant sites.
